site_title: DFI Retail Group divests 22.2% stake in Robinsons Retail for undisclosed sum
summary: DFI Retail Group has divested 22.2% of its stake in Robinsons Retail for an undisclosed sum, allowing the company to redeploy capital to support growth and enhance shareholder returns. The transaction is a "significant step" in DFI's evolution as an operating company, according to CEO Scott Price. DFI will review the use of the divestment proceeds to support its long-term growth priorities, including expanding digital retail media and enhancing omnichannel capabilities. The company remains confident in Robinsons Retail's long-term prospects.

site_title: Stocks to watch: IHH Healthcare, Keppel, Jardine Matheson, Cordlife
summary: Keppel appoints former DBS CEO Piyush Gupta as deputy chairman and non-executive independent director, effective July 1. IHH Healthcare posted a 33% drop in net profit to RM514 million for its first quarter, while Jardine Matheson Holdings announced Lincoln Pan as CEO-designate ahead of John Witt's retirement in November. Cordlife appointed Novus Corporate Finance as independent financial adviser for a conditional cash partial offer from a Thai company.

site_title: US regulator drops lawsuit against Binance
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) dropped its civil lawsuit against cryptocurrency exchange Binance and its majority shareholder Changpeng Zhao, citing the exercise of discretion and policy. This move comes after Zhao pleaded guilty to violating US anti-money-laundering requirements and served a four-month prison sentence. The SEC's decision does not reflect its position in other litigation proceedings. Binance has been accused of allowing criminal organizations to launder funds through its platform in several countries.

Stablecoins, a type of cryptocurrency designed to maintain a constant value, usually a 1:1 US dollar peg, are commonly used by crypto traders to move funds between tokens.

site_title: US asks judge to dismiss criminal charge over Boeing 737 Max crashes
summary: The US Justice Department asked a federal judge in Texas to dismiss its criminal case against Boeing over two fatal 737 Max crashes, as part of a proposed settlement that calls for Boeing to pay over $1.1 billion in fees and fines, while strengthening internal quality and safety measures. In return, Boeing will avoid criminal prosecution, following a previous deal that was rejected by the judge. The case had been set to go to trial on June 23.

site_title: Trump says he plans to double steel, aluminum tariffs to 50%
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a plan to double steel and aluminum tariffs to 50% from 25%, intensifying his global trade war. The move aims to secure the US steel industry and keep jobs for steel workers. The tariffs will take effect on June 4 and apply to both steel and aluminum products. The increase is seen as a significant escalation of Trump's trade policies, which have already affected steel imports from various countries, including China and Canada.

images.alt_text: On a Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania-area stage decorated with signs celebrating “American steel”, Trump appeared to signal he would support a long-sought tie-up between the Japanese and US companies that he once opposed.

site_title: Joint venture by Boustead Projects’ unit clinches JTC tender to develop industrial facility on Tukang Innovation Drive site
summary: A joint venture between Boustead Projects' unit BP-Innovue and UIB has won a tender to develop an industrial facility on Tukang Innovation Drive site. The 18,687 sq m land parcel will be transformed into a multi-user industrial facility with heavy vehicle parking, marking the first development project under the industrial government land sales programme to secure a 33-year land lease. The development is expected to have minimal impact on Boustead's financial performance.

site_title: Liverpool sign Frimpong as Alexander-Arnold leaves
summary: Liverpool has signed Dutch international defender Jeremie Frimpong from Bayer Leverkusen on a five-year deal reportedly worth 35 million euros. The move comes after Trent Alexander-Arnold joined Real Madrid, and Frimpong is seen as a ready-made replacement for the England full-back. Frimpong, 24, made 53 appearances for Leverkusen, including their Bundesliga title win in 2023/24. Liverpool is also in talks with Leverkusen over signing midfielder Florian Wirtz, who would be the club's most expensive signing in history.

site_title: France, Singapore to cooperate in areas such as maritime, nuclear energy under new Comprehensive Strategic Partnership
summary: Singapore and France have upgraded their bilateral ties to a Comprehensive Strategic Partnership (CSP), the highest possible tier of cooperation. The partnership covers areas such as defence, economy, emerging technologies, energy, and people-to-people exchanges. The two countries will deepen cooperation in areas like quantum computing, civil nuclear energy, and maritime transport. France will also enhance its engagement in the region, with Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong welcoming its increased presence. The partnership aims to promote multilateralism and a new rules-based global order.

site_title: Acrophyte Hospitality Trust undergoes strategic review, in talks for potential transaction involving stapled securities
summary: Acrophyte Hospitality Trust is undergoing a strategic review, evaluating a range of options, including a potential transaction involving its stapled securities. Despite ongoing discussions, there is no certainty that any transaction will materialize. The trust, which owns seven hotels slated for asset enhancement initiatives in 2025, reported a 7.7% decline in revenue and a 12.8% drop in operating profit in Q1 2025. The review follows a similar strategic review by Frasers Hospitality Trust, with its sponsor renewing a bid to privatize the stapled group.

site_title: Trump celebrates Nippon Steel 'deal' with rally at Pennsylvania plant
summary: US President Donald Trump attended a rally in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, to celebrate a potential partnership between Nippon Steel and US Steel, a deal he once opposed. The planned acquisition, worth $14.9 billion, has been contentious due to opposition from union leadership and national security reviews. Trump's visit appeared to signal support for the merger, but the deal's status remains uncertain, with the timeline for a formal approval or rejection set to expire next Thursday. The partnership aims to create 70,000 jobs and add $14 billion to the US economy.

site_title: AI to send Asia’s data centre spending and power needs up; Morgan Stanley picks the winners
summary: Morgan Stanley analysts predict Asia's data centre spending and power needs will double to $200 billion by 2030, driven by AI adoption and advanced manufacturing. Power consumption across Asia is outpacing forecasts, with data centres alone expected to consume 100 GW of electricity by 2030, accounting for a sixth of Asia's incremental power demand. Analysts identify grid operators, natural gas-fired plants, and infrastructure firms focused on clean energy as beneficiaries, with several stocks receiving "overweight" calls, including Reliance Industries and Tenaga Nasional.

site_title: China's central bank injects 700 billion yuan of outright reverse repos in May
summary: China's central bank injected 700 billion yuan into its banking system through outright reverse repos in May, maintaining "reasonably ample liquidity." This move comes amid concerns over US-China decoupling, with analysts predicting the PBOC may resume government bond purchases as early as July or August to counter economic risks. The decision suggests a net withdrawal of 200 billion yuan from the system via the tool.

site_title: Fuji Offset Plates Manufacturing shares jump 67% after former Dyna-Mac CEO AC Lim buys S$4.5 million stake
summary: Former Dyna-Mac CEO AC Lim has invested S$4.5 million in Fuji Offset Plates Manufacturing (FOP), purchasing 10 million new shares and increasing his stake to 16.7%. The shares jumped 67.1% after the announcement, with Lim set to join the board as a controlling shareholder. FOP expects the investment to strengthen its financial position and enhance growth opportunities, with net proceeds to be used for business expansion and capital expenditure.

site_title: Trump tariffs stay in place for now, after appellate ruling
summary: US President Donald Trump's tariffs on China and other trading partners remain in place for now, following an appeals court's decision to preserve the tariffs. The US Court of International Trade had previously blocked most of the tariffs, ruling that Trump overstepped his authority. The appeals court's decision allows the appeals process to proceed, giving the White House 10 days to halt affected tariffs. Trump's administration has expressed confidence that the decision will be overturned on appeal, while China has urged the US to scrap the levies.

site_title: OKP unit wins S$258.3 million LTA contract to construct new cycling paths in east
summary: OKP Holdings, a Singapore-based infrastructure and civil engineering company, has won a S$258.3 million contract from the Land Transport Authority (LTA) to construct new cycling paths in the eastern region of Singapore. The contract, valued at S$735.8 million, marks the largest award for OKP to date and the fourth LTA contract won by its subsidiaries, totaling S$617.8 million. The project, spanning 72 months, will convert existing footpaths to cycling paths and create new pedestrian paths, and is expected to contribute positively to OKP's growth trajectory.

site_title: China's manufacturing activity contracts amid trade tension
summary: China's manufacturing activity contracted for the second month in May, with the official purchasing managers' index (PMI) at 49.5, below the 50-mark separating growth from contraction. The new orders sub-index rose to 49.8 and new export orders sub-index rose to 47.5, amid trade tensions with the US. Analysts expect Beijing to deliver more monetary and fiscal stimulus to support growth. China's economy expanded faster than expected in the first quarter, with a growth target of about 5% this year, but US tariffs could drive momentum sharply lower.

images.alt_text: China's official purchasing managers’ index fell to 49.0 in April versus 50.5 in March, below the 50-mark separating growth from contraction, and missing a median forecast of 49.8 in a Reuters poll.

site_title: Energy Market Authority chairman Richard Lim to step down; ex-perm sec Tan Ching Yee to assume role
summary: Energy Market Authority (EMA) chairman Richard Lim, 71, will step down on September 30 after five years of leading the board. He will be succeeded by former permanent secretary Tan Ching Yee, 60, who will become deputy chairperson from June 1 to September 30 before taking over as chairperson on October 1. Under Lim's leadership, EMA has strengthened Singapore's energy security and advanced its energy transition, including the deployment of solar energy and low-carbon electricity imports. Tan brings experience in various leadership roles, including representing Singapore at the G20.

images.alt_text: Lai Chung Han (left) will take over Tan Ching Yee (right) as chairman of the board of Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore.

site_title: Digitalising for resilience by turning disruption into opportunity
summary: Business leaders say resilience in today's economy hinges on adapting quickly to disruption. With rising costs, talent crunches, and economic uncertainty, companies need to build agility and anticipate changes to weather storms. Digital tools are critical enablers of this agility, automating routine tasks, improving productivity, and enhancing customer experience. To achieve resilience, businesses must set measurable goals, prioritize digitalization, and balance technology with customer understanding and core operations. Digital accounting tools provide real-time visibility, enabling quick decision-making and strategic foresight, and can help businesses control costs, forecast, and make informed decisions.

site_title: Thousands rally in Nepali pro-monarchy protests
summary: Thousands of Nepali royalists gathered in Kathmandu on May 30, demanding the restoration of the monarchy and chanting slogans in support of the deposed king. The protests come amid dissatisfaction over political instability, corruption, and slow economic development. Demonstrators, including 58-year-old Prem Bahadur Magar, called for a constitutional monarchy and a Hindu nation to preserve national identity. The rallies follow a day of marches by the Communist Party of Nepal, which opposed the restoration of the monarchy.

images.alt_text: Nepal's Prime Minister Pushpa Kamal Dahal was forced to either resign or prove his majority in parliament after his largest ally, the liberal Communist Unified Marxist Leninist (UML) party withdrew support last week.

site_title: US consumer spending growth slows while inflation remains soft
summary: US consumer spending growth slowed in April, with inflation-adjusted personal spending rising 0.1% after a 0.7% increase the previous month. Core inflation, excluding food and energy, rose 2.5% from a year earlier, the smallest annual advance in over four years. The modest spending increase reflected a rise in services, while durable goods outlays declined. The US merchandise-trade deficit narrowed in April, with imports decreasing by the largest-ever margin. Federal Reserve policymakers are likely to keep interest rates unchanged due to uncertainty surrounding tariffs and their impact on the economy.

site_title: Malaysia hosts, Asean hopes, but now comes the hard part
summary: Malaysia hosts the 46th Asean Summit, aiming to boost regional ties and future-proof the bloc amidst rising global headwinds. The two-day gathering, held alongside the Asean-GCC and Asean-GCC-China summits, focused on political stability, greener growth, and tighter digital ties. Asean member states reached internal consensus on a ceasefire in Myanmar and progress in long-stalled negotiations for a Code of Conduct in the South China Sea. The adoption of the Kuala Lumpur Declaration, a foundational blueprint for Asean's Community Vision 2045, aims to make the bloc a more assertive global player by mid-century.

site_title: How an agonising relationship with his dad shaped Xi Jinping
summary: Biographer Joseph Torigian's new book, "The Party's Interests Come First," offers a rare glimpse into the childhood of Xi Jinping, the world's most powerful man. Xi Jinping's relationship with his father, Xi Zhongxun, had a profound impact on his life, shaping his dedication to the Chinese Communist Party and his authoritarian leadership style. Xi Jinping's experiences of poverty, imprisonment, and his family's suffering during the Cultural Revolution have hardened him into a man who believes in restoring China's greatness at any cost. The book suggests that Xi Jinping's loyalty to the party and his family stems from a Bolshevik political culture that glamorizes suffering and dedication to the cause, influencing his autocratic rule and Taiwan policy.

site_title: Livingstone Health back in the black, logs H2 profit of S$0.4 million from streamlining efforts, higher revenue
summary: Livingstone Health Holdings Ltd has reported a net profit of S$0.4 million for the second half-year, reversing a net loss of S$2.9 million in the previous year. The company's revenue rose 17.9% to S$14.2 million, driven by higher revenue from all business segments. Streamlining efforts and cost reductions contributed to the turnaround, with the company reducing its spending on employee benefits and operating expenses. Full-year net profit is now S$0.6 million, swinging back into the black from a full-year net loss of S$2.9 million.

summary: Elon Musk bid farewell to Donald Trump in an Oval Office meeting, handing Trump a golden key to the White House. Musk, who left as Trump's cost-cutter-in-chief, vowed to remain a "friend and advisor" to the president, despite criticism over his role. Trump praised Musk's "incredible service" and predicted his return, saying he would continue to "cut costs and make America great again." Musk wore a black eye, which he attributed to his 5-year-old son, and denied allegations of drug abuse.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as China trade tensions fuel unease
summary: US stocks closed mixed on Friday, May 30, as trade tensions with China fueled unease. The Dow Jones Industrial Average edged up 0.1% to 42,270.07, while the S&P 500 Index remained flat at 5,911.69. Despite an inflation gauge cooling, investors remained nervous after President Trump accused China of violating a tariff de-escalation deal, sparking fears of a return to a confrontational approach towards the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: MacDermid Alpha Electronics Solutions expands Singapore production facility
summary: MacDermid Alpha Electronics Solutions has expanded its production facility in Tuas, Singapore, doubling its production capacity for its flagship silver sintering paste, Agromax. The move aims to meet rising global demand for the material, driven by the growth of the electric vehicle (EV) sector. The expansion is expected to add around 100 new jobs and strengthen the company's global supply chain and market responsiveness. The company's vice-president stated that it is optimistic about its position, despite US President Donald Trump's tariffs, and is confident in Singapore's strong manufacturing capabilities.

site_title: Jardine Matheson Holdings names Lincoln Pan as CEO-designate ahead of group managing director John Witt’s retirement
summary: Hong Kong-based conglomerate Jardine Matheson Holdings announced the appointment of Lincoln Pan as chief executive-designate, effective December 1, replacing retiring group managing director John Witt. Pan, a partner at alternative investment business PAG, brings extensive investment experience in the Asia-Pacific region. Witt, who has served as group managing director since 2020, will step down on November 30. The appointment is seen as a strategic move to implement the group's long-term strategy to build bigger, better businesses.

summary: South-east Asian environmental, social, and governance (ESG) stock indices have outperformed their vanilla benchmarks since 2022. A new report highlights the region's growing commitment to ESG investing, with Sembcorp building a regional pipeline for sustainable energy. Meanwhile, Temasek's sustainability-aligned investments reached S$46 billion in FY2025, and Singapore is considering introducing carbon offsetting legislation for airlines. The growth of ESG investing in the region is seen as a positive trend, but Asean still needs to demonstrate strong returns on ESG projects to attract private capital.

summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) of Singapore has granted a conditional licence to Singa Renewables, a joint venture between RGE and TotalEnergies, to import 1 gigawatt of low-carbon electricity from Indonesia to Singapore. This licence marks a step forward in Singapore's efforts to decarbonize its power sector, with the goal of reducing carbon emissions from the sector to around 40% by 2035. The licence allows Singa Renewables to bring in low-carbon electricity, creating jobs and contributing to the growth of the clean energy sector in partner countries like Indonesia.

site_title: Pentagon chief warns of imminent China threat, pushes Asian allies to hike defence spending
summary: US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth warned on Saturday that China poses a real and potentially imminent threat, urging Asian allies to increase defense spending to counter the growing Chinese military presence. Hegseth emphasized that China's actions, including increasing military pressure around Taiwan, could have devastating consequences for the Indo-Pacific region. He also encouraged European allies to increase their defense spending, citing the example of NATO members pledging to spend 5% of their GDP on defense. Hegseth's comments come as China's Defense Minister Dong Jun skips the Shangri-La Dialogue, a major Asian security forum.

site_title: UK business confidence hits 9-month high in boost for Starmer
summary: The Lloyds Business Barometer sentiment gauge reached a 9-month high of 50 in May, driven by a sharp increase in economic optimism following a market rebound and easing of global trade tensions. This boost in business confidence, led by a rise in confidence among construction businesses and improved sentiment across most UK regions, suggests the UK economy's resilience despite still-elevated inflation. The jump erases the drop seen in April, following US President Donald Trump's tariff hikes, and may indicate a stronger position for the next quarter.

images.alt_text: A shopper browses in a store in London, Britain, May 21, 2025. According to the Office of National Statistics, the UK inflation rate rose to 3.5 per cent in April. It is the highest level since February 2025 driven by sharp rises in household bills, and higher food, vehicle duty and airfare costs.

site_title: US judge sentences ex-Goldman Sachs banker to two years over 1MDB scandal
summary: A US judge sentenced former Goldman Sachs banker Timothy Leissner to two years in prison for his role in the 1MDB scandal, a massive bribery and kickback scheme involving billions of dollars. Leissner pleaded guilty to US bribery and money laundering counts and cooperated with the probe, turning over electronic devices and providing details that led to charges against others. The case is the only criminal case filed against Goldman Sachs in its 156-year history, with the firm dismissing Leissner's cooperation as a result of his "brazen and audacious" conduct.

site_title: Macron touts ‘positive new’ Asia-Europe alliance amid US-China rivalry
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron announced a proposed Asia-Europe alliance aimed at countering the US-China rivalry and promoting a stable, rules-based order. Macron emphasized the need for openness, consistency, and cooperation among nations, calling for a "third way" that balances competition with cooperation. He urged Asian countries, particularly India and members of the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership, to work together. Macron also warned of the risks of nuclear proliferation and China's growing influence in the region, leaving the door open for China and the US to join the proposed coalition.

images.alt_text: President Macron giving the keynote address at the Shangri-La Dialogue Summit in Singapore. He said Asia and Europe have a common interest in preventing the disintegration of the global order.

site_title: New World seeks more banks to join up to US$2 billion loan
summary: New World Development is seeking additional banks to join a US$2 billion loan, backed by its Victoria Dockside asset, amid concerns over its debt burden. Existing lenders have declined to participate due to separate refinancing engagements, with Deutsche Bank arranging the deal. The company aims to use the loan proceeds to repay debt and has secured over HK$35 billion in commitments, approximately 40% of its target. New World faces liquidity issues due to a prolonged property slump in Hong Kong and mainland China.

summary: Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong emphasized the importance of agile partnerships, regional integration, and reforming global institutions to help Asia face global challenges. site_title: Tokyo prices rising most in two years, keeps BOJ on hike path
summary: Tokyo's core inflation rate accelerated to 3.5% in April, driven by rising food costs, particularly rice prices that doubled year-on-year. The BOJ's policy stance is also influenced by the US trade policies, with potential tariff exemptions potentially deterring rate hikes. The government has taken steps to address the issue, including releasing stockpiled rice and unveiling a stimulus package, but public discontent over rising living costs remains a concern ahead of a summer election.

site_title: Tesla targets June 12 launch of robotaxi service in Austin
summary: Tesla plans to launch its robotaxi service in Austin on June 12, according to a source familiar with the matter. The service will use driverless vehicles with cameras and insurance, and will initially roll out 10 vehicles before expanding to 1,000. The city of Austin has set up a task force to coordinate with Tesla and other autonomy companies, but does not regulate self-driving vehicles. Tesla's shares rose 1.1% after the announcement, as the company aims to reshape its business around driverless vehicles and artificial intelligence.

summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong stated that Israel's restrictions on aid supplies to Gaza may be a breach of international humanitarian law, calling its response "unacceptable" and "gone too far". summary: US crude futures fell on Friday as traders anticipated OPEC+ would boost oil output for July, contrary to previous forecasts. Brent crude futures dropped 25 cents to $63.90 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 15 cents to $60.79 a barrel. The expected increase in output may prompt a supply-side response to balance the global surplus of 2.2 million barrels per day. summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr has retained his defense, justice, and interior secretaries in a government reshuffle aimed at improving public service quality. summary: The US financial landscape is shifting as giants like BlackRock, Apollo, and Blackstone expand into private markets, leveraging their influence and assets to challenge traditional boundaries. site_title: Can gold return to the monetary throne?
summary: A return to gold as a monetary commodity could occur in a hypothetical economic collapse, but this does not mean gold is real money under current conditions. Global uncertainty may force humanity to rely on old tools, including gold, in monetary relations, but a single world currency based on credit relations is likely to emerge in the future.

The US stock market's rise the previous night, driven by delayed tariffs on Europe, also influenced Singapore's market. Despite this, portfolio manager Peter Bates remained bullish on US stocks, citing long-term opportunities.

site_title: SunMoon sinks to S$1.5 million loss in FY2025 despite higher revenue
summary: SunMoon Food Company, a Singapore-based fruit distributor, reported a net loss of S$1.5 million for FY2025, despite a 25% increase in revenue to S$33.8 million. The loss was attributed to lower gross margins from clearing slow-moving inventories and an expected credit loss on trade receivables. Loss per share was S$0.00168, compared to earnings per share of S$0.00003 the previous year. The company's shares rose 14.3% to S$0.016.

site_title: Losing weight – back to basics
summary: A recent meta-analysis found that Type 2 diabetes drugs, such as Saxenda and Ozempic, which offer weight loss as a side effect, lead to weight regain within two years of stopping the medication. This suggests that a more sustainable approach to weight loss is diet and exercise. Experts and individuals who have achieved long-term weight loss through these methods share their experiences, emphasizing the importance of a balanced lifestyle.

site_title: Trump says Fannie Mae to keep US guarantee as public firm
summary: US President Donald Trump has announced that the US government will retain guarantees and an oversight role over Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, despite plans to pursue a public offering for the mortgage giants. The companies, under government conservatorship since the 2008 financial crisis, have returned to steady profitability. Trump's move aims to alleviate concerns over the risk of a government guarantee being removed, which could impact mortgage rates.

images.alt_text: “Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are doing very well, throwing off a lot of CASH, and the time would seem to be right. Stay tuned!” Trump wrote on his Truth Social website.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, Amara, Valuetronics
summary: OCBC announced key leadership changes to its global wholesale banking franchise, effective October 1. Elaine Heng will succeed Linus Goh as head of global commercial banking. Amara's takeover bid for a hotel group was deemed "fair and reasonable" by an independent adviser. Valuetronics posted a 3.1% increase in net profit. CapitaLand Ascendas Reit's trading was halted due to proposed acquisitions, and Econ Healthcare's shares were suspended on Wednesday morning.

site_title: SLA launches tender to transform historic Moulmein Road site into lifestyle hub
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) has launched a tender to transform the historic site of 2 Moulmein Road into a contemporary lifestyle hub. The site, which has 44 state-managed buildings, will feature co-living spaces, an art gallery, F&B, health and fitness, and education services. The transformed site will cater to families and multi-generational communities, with a focus on sustainability and inclusive place-making. The tender, which closes on August 6, will evaluate proposals based on price and quality, with a higher weightage on quality to encourage innovative concepts.

site_title: PSA Corp, FairPrice Foundation among winners of AIC’s Friends of Community Care Awards
summary: PSA Corp and FairPrice Foundation won the Agency for Integrated Care's (AIC) Friends of Community Care Awards, recognizing their efforts in supporting seniors through various programs. PSA Corp's PSA Health@Home (H@H) programme supports senior citizens, while FairPrice Foundation focuses on food and nutrition for lower-income households, community engagement, and worker welfare. The awards aim to promote community care and address Singapore's rapidly ageing population, with the number of seniors expected to increase from 76,000 to 122,000 by 2030.

site_title: New Zealand central bank cuts cash rate by 25 bps
summary: New Zealand's central bank cut its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 3.25% in its sixth consecutive rate cut. The decision was in line with a Reuters poll and reflects growing risks to economic growth from US trade policies. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) forecast a slightly deeper easing cycle than previously expected, with interest rates potentially reaching 2.85% in 2026. The decision aims to maintain price stability amid inflation within the target band and spare capacity in the economy.

images.alt_text: The RBNZ will publish its decision at 2 pm local time on Wednesday and governor Christian Hawkesby will hold a press conference an hour later.

site_title: IMF warns UK to keep budget in check or risk market revolt
summary: The International Monetary Fund warned UK Chancellor Rachel Reeves to stick to her fiscal rules and keep spending under control to avoid a market backlash. The IMF recommended covering any additional spending with other savings or tax rises, citing limited headroom and a high national debt. The warning comes ahead of the June 11 Spending Review, which will set budget limits for government departments for the next three years, and follows recent market reactions to hints of fiscal laxity.

site_title: Tencent Music buys SM Entertainment stake in K-pop bet
summary: Tencent Music Entertainment Group, a subsidiary of China's gaming and social media leader Tencent, is buying a nearly 10% stake in SM Entertainment, a South Korean entertainment company, for $180 million. This marks a rare Chinese investment in a South Korean company, following China's expected lifting of its nearly decade-old ban on K-pop performances in mainland China. The deal comes as SM Entertainment's shares have rallied 72% this year, driven by expectations of China lifting the ban and shielding South Korean entertainment stocks from tariff wars.

site_title: Asia: Stocks track Wall Street rally as trade fears ease, eyes on Japan debt
summary: Asian stocks rose on Wednesday, tracking a Wall Street rally, as traders welcomed forecast-beating US consumer confidence data and a drop in bond yields. The US President's delay in implementing 50% tariffs on China eased trade fears, boosting markets. Investors also eyed Japan's crucial sale of 40-year government bonds, which may alleviate concerns over rising debt costs. The rally was also fueled by positive news on US-EU trade talks and a cut in interest rates by New Zealand's central bank.

site_title: UBS’s Iqbal Khan sees rich customer demand for alternative assets
summary: UBS's Asia-Pacific chief, Iqbal Khan, says wealthy customers are seeking to buy more alternative assets to diversify investments amid market volatility. The bank has seen a significant growth in alternative investments in client portfolios, but still has room for diversification. UBS is also expected to face rising competition from regional lenders such as HSBC Holdings and DBS Group Holdings. The bank's markets unit posted a record performance in the first quarter, driven by geopolitical turmoil and trading activity.

site_title: Government may remove 15-month wait-out period when HDB resale prices begin to moderate: Chee Hong Tat
summary: Singapore's government may review or remove a 15-month wait-out period for private property owners to downgrade to non-subsidized HDB resale flats, when resale prices moderate. The wait-out period was introduced in 2022 to curb demand and prices. Resale prices have shown moderation, with a 1.6% growth rate over the last three months, slower than the 2.6% increase in the fourth quarter of last year. Minister for National Development Chee Hong Tat attributes the increase to a supply and demand issue, and expects prices to moderate further when new flats reach their minimum occupancy period starting in 2026.

site_title: US warns Pirelli risks restrictions due to Chinese investor
summary: The US Commerce Department's Bureau of Industry and Security has warned Italy's Pirelli & C that vehicles using its advanced CyberTyre technology could be restricted from sale in the US due to concerns over the influence of its Chinese investor, Sinochem, which holds a 37% stake. Pirelli's shares fell 3.3% following the news. The advisory is part of a new rule restricting the import and domestic sale of cars using certain Chinese and Russian technology. Pirelli is seeking to strengthen its foothold in the US market despite a growing governance feud with Sinochem.

site_title: France-Indonesia pact could lead to new Rafale jet orders, says Macron
summary: France and Indonesia signed a preliminary defence pact, potentially leading to new orders for French military equipment, including Rafale fighter jets and Scorpene submarines. The deal, valued at $8.1 billion, includes 42 Rafale jets ordered in 2022, with deliveries expected in 2026. The pact also includes submarine development and ammunition agreements. French President Emmanuel Macron expressed hope for new orders and partnerships, while Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto emphasized the importance of upgrading military hardware and developing the defence industry.

summary: Malaysia is poised to benefit from a potential sell-off in US assets due to Trump administration's trade policies, according to CIMB Group Holdings CEO Novan Amirudin. Strong domestic demand and Malaysia's stable political environment are expected to anchor growth, despite a slightly lower-than-expected 4.5-5.5% official growth estimate. A planned special economic zone with Singapore and investments in sectors like energy transition and manufacturing are also expected to attract foreign investment.

site_title: A conspiracy of silence
summary: A new book, "Original Sin: President Biden's Decline, Its Cover-Up and His Disastrous Choice to Run Again," by Jake Tapper and Alex Thompson, reveals that the Democratic Party, White House staff, and Biden campaign concealed President Joe Biden's declining mental state and health issues, prioritizing his re-election over his well-being. The book details instances of Biden's confusion, forgetfulness, and incoherence, including a disastrous debate with Donald Trump in 2024. The authors argue that the party's decision to hide Biden's decline handed the election to Trump, driven by a desire to avoid discussing the president's mental state and fearing it would play into Trump's hands.

site_title: New initiatives to facilitate cross-border data transfer and multimodal AI model Meralion
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority of Singapore (IMDA) announced new initiatives to facilitate cross-border data transfer and launched a multimodal AI model called Meralion. A Global Cross-Border Privacy Rules (CBPR) certification will give businesses certainty in international data transfers, with nine economies initially participating, including the US, Australia, and Japan. Meralion, developed by A*Star and I²R, can understand emotions, context, and intent across South-east Asia's multiple languages and cultures, and a consortium will be established to accelerate its adoption and improve its performance.

site_title: SingHealth Duke-NUS’ AI spinoff inks MOUs with Roche, ST Engineering to improve healthcare operations
summary: Enigma Health, a healthcare AI spinoff from SingHealth Duke-NUS, has signed separate memorandums of understanding with Roche and ST Engineering to expand its agentic AI platform. The platform can reason and act autonomously, optimizing workflow and streamlining data-intensive processes. The agreements will enable Roche to accelerate clinical trial recruitment and improve business intelligence, while ST Engineering will integrate Enigma's small language model into its Agil Genie Studio platform. The partnerships aim to improve healthcare operations and oversight, with a focus on patient care and regulatory compliance.

site_title: South-east Asia sees near 150% rise in heart disease, study shows
summary: A study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation and the National University of Singapore found a 148% rise in heart disease cases in South-east Asia over the past three decades, with 37 million people affected and 1.7 million deaths in 2021. The main causes include high blood pressure, dietary risks, air pollution, and smoking. The study also highlights the growing burden of mental disorders, with over 80 million people in the region affected, and road injuries, which claimed hundreds of thousands of lives in 2021. Immediate action is needed to prevent these preventable health conditions from worsening.

site_title: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit to buy Tai Seng data centre, Science Park building for S$700.2 million
summary: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit has entered conditional agreements to acquire a Tier III colocation data centre at 9 Tai Seng Drive and a premium business space property at 5 Science Park Drive in Singapore for S$700.2 million. The deals will raise the trust's Singapore portfolio value by 6.6% to S$11.7 billion, with the technology sector accounting for 67% of its total assets under management. The acquisitions are expected to cost S$724.6 million, partly funded by a proposed private placement of new units aiming to raise at least S$500 million.

site_title: Nomura faces rare vote over shareholder’s name-change proposal
summary: Nomura Holdings will vote on a shareholder proposal to change its name to Nomura Securities Group at its upcoming general meeting, the first time in 13 years. The proposal aims to return the company to its founder's principles after scandals, including manipulative trading. The board is opposed to the change, citing the company's current name is widely recognized as the holding company of a financial services group. Activist investors are pushing for more shareholder returns, increasing pressure on Japanese companies.

site_title: Nissan plans one trillion yen funding with backing from UK government
summary: Nissan plans to raise over 1 trillion yen (S$8.9 billion) through debt and asset sales to address a looming loan repayment wall. The company aims to issue convertible securities and bonds, including a £1 billion loan guaranteed by the UK government. Nissan also plans to sell stakes in Renault and AESC Group, and close plants in South Africa and Mexico. The move aims to boost liquidity and avoid an operating loss of up to 450 billion yen, as the company faces a cash dwindle and internal forecasts predict zero cash by March 2026.

site_title: Temu-owner PDD Holdings profit dives as it faces challenges at home and abroad
summary: PDD Holdings, the parent company of Chinese e-commerce platform Pinduoduo, reported a 47% decline in first-quarter net profit to 14.7 billion yuan due to intense domestic competition and global trade uncertainty. The company's US-listed shares fell 17%. Analysts attribute the decline to weaker operating margins, impacted by US tariffs, and a prolonged property crisis in China casting a shadow over consumer spending. The price war among China's largest online e-commerce platforms has sparked concerns about the long-term health of the industry.

site_title: TSMC to open chip design centre in Munich, could later support AI development
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) will open a chip design centre in Munich, Germany, supporting European customers in designing high-density, high-performance chips for applications like artificial intelligence. The centre, set to open in the third quarter of 2025, will work on advanced manufacturing processes for AI and other applications. TSMC's move comes as Europe formulates a strategy to catch up with the US and China in AI development, with the company also investing in a joint venture to build a 10 billion euro microchip manufacturing plant in Dresden, Germany.

site_title: Heritage bakery Old Seng Choong heads to China despite economic uncertainty
summary: Singapore's heritage bakery Old Seng Choong plans to open its first overseas outlet in Shanghai, China, despite economic uncertainty. Founder Daniel Tay hopes to establish 200 to 300 stores in China via franchising and joint ventures. Old Seng Choong will supply traditional cakes, cookies, and pastries, with a smaller menu focusing on uniquely Singapore flavors. The brand's parent company, Foodgnostic, already supplies other Singapore brands, including Cat & the Fiddle, and has factories in China. Tay sees China as a big market to tap into, with a population of 1.4 billion people.

site_title: Gold stages rebound as US dollar, Treasury yields slip
summary: Gold prices rose 0.5% to $3,314.19 an ounce on Wednesday, driven by a decline in the US dollar index and lower US bond yields. Investors await the US core PCE price index report for interest rate clues. The US dollar index fell 0.1%, making gold more attractive for other currency holders. Treasury yields declined, easing concerns over rising global government debt supply. The US President's decision to roll back tariff threats also boosted risk sentiment in financial markets.

site_title: GM to invest US$888 million for engine production at New York facility
summary: General Motors is investing $888 million in its Tonawanda propulsion plant in Buffalo, New York, to increase engine production and build a next-generation V8 engine. The investment supports the sixth generation of GM's V-8 engines used in full-size trucks and SUVs, expected to be more fuel-efficient. The move comes after the company pulled back on some of its previously announced EV investments amid slower-than-expected market demand. The project will support 870 jobs at the plant, including 177 deemed at risk, and the state plans to provide up to $16.96 million in tax credits.

site_title: Singapore households’ debt up, but assets growth more than keeps pace
summary: Singapore households' debt has increased, rising 5.2% year-over-year to S$384.1 billion in the first quarter of 2025, but household assets have grown at a faster pace, up 7.8% to S$3.49 trillion. Despite this, the liabilities-to-assets ratio has fallen to 11%, indicating that fewer assets are being financed by debt. Household net worth has remained positive, growing 8.1% to S$3.1 trillion, with personal disposable income increasing 5.2% to S$93.3 billion. Economists expect the debt-servicing burden to ease with falling interest rates, and the economy is expected to expand at a modest 1.3% in 2025.

site_title: Australia’s monthly CPI higher than estimates, Aussie edges up
summary: Australia's monthly CPI rose slightly faster than expected in April, staying at 2.4%, with the trimmed mean measure increasing to 2.8%. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has been monitoring core inflation, which has been suppressed by government rebates and subsidies. The RBA cut interest rates last week, citing decreasing risks of price pressures, but with the Trump administration's tariff regime threatening global activity, inflation is likely to take a backseat to economic concerns.

summary: US Federal Reserve President John Williams emphasized the need for a strong response to inflation deviating from the central bank's target. Given uncertainty around the impact of US tariffs and trade policy, central banks should prioritize avoiding costly mistakes over perfect solutions. Williams stated that responding "relatively strongly" to inflation deviations can prevent persistent inflation, which could become permanent.

summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index reached a 3-month high of 8,448.5 points, up 0.5% as banking and mining stocks surged ahead of April inflation data. Financials rose 0.4% and miners climbed 0.4%, despite a slump in iron ore prices. Shares of BHP, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue added 1%, 0.1%, and 1.7%, respectively. site_title: Thailand PM presents 3.78 trillion baht budget to parliament to support lacklustre economy
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra has proposed a 3.78 trillion baht budget for the 2026 fiscal year, aiming to revive and drive the economy towards sustainable growth. The budget projects a 0.7% rise in spending and a 0.7% drop in the budget deficit, with growth expected at 2.3-3.3% and inflation at 0.5-1.5%. The budget comes amid tensions in the Pheu Thai Party-led coalition, particularly over the government's casino bill and constitutional reform. The budget is expected to pass, but its passage could be influenced by the government's ability to navigate these internal disputes.

Waiting times for berth space have risen by 77% in Bremerhaven, 37% in Antwerp, and 49% in Hamburg, while the US-China tariff truce has yet to unleash a surge in ships across the Pacific. The EU-US dispute and Trump's tariff threats are adding to the uncertainty, with shipping lines expected to hike freight rates in response to delays and higher costs.

site_title: Interest costs fall for S-Reits in Q1, but US tariffs cloud outlook
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) saw interest costs ease in Q1, with nearly three-quarters experiencing flat to moderate declines. However, looming US tariffs cast a shadow over their prospects for the second half of the year. Hospitality S-Reits, such as Far East Hospitality Trust and CDL Hospitality Trust, were among the worst performers, while retail S-Reits with suburban assets showed resilience. Analysts expect the operating trend for Q2 to be similar to Q1, but remain optimistic about the longer-term performance of S-Reits, driven by falling interest rates and potential DPU growth in FY2026 and FY2027.

site_title: US climate pullback threatens planned debt-for-nature deals
summary: The US International Development Finance Corporation's (DFC) involvement in "debt-for-nature" swaps, which reduce a country's debt in exchange for conservation commitments, is at risk of unraveling or needing reworking due to concerns that crucial US backing is drying up under President Donald Trump. The DFC has been a key player, providing political risk insurance for over half of the deals done over the last five years, but its CEO-in-waiting and government efficiency chief have criticized its climate work. Several countries, including Angola and Zambia, may need to rework or abandon their swap plans due to DFC uncertainty.

site_title: China publishes draft guidance for online-platform merchant fees
summary: China's State Administration for Market Regulation has published draft guidelines for online-platform merchant fees, aiming to reduce merchants' burdens and improve fee-related compliance frameworks. The guidelines require platforms to set flexible pricing strategies and offer better support to smaller businesses. The move comes as Chinese merchants face pressure from a sluggish local economy and a trade war with the US, with complaints about "complicated and non-transparent" charges on platforms. The deadline for feedback on the draft guidance is June 3.

site_title: Saudi Aramco considers asset sales to free up funds: sources
summary: Saudi Aramco, the world's largest oil-producing company, is exploring asset sales to free up funds amid lower crude prices. The company plans to slash dividend payouts by nearly a third this year and has asked investment bankers to pitch ideas for raising funds from its assets. Aramco is also looking to improve efficiency and cut costs, with asset sales considered an option. The move aims to help the Saudi government balance its budget deficit, which the International Monetary Fund says requires an oil price of over $90 per barrel.

site_title: Burnout, boredom or bad PR? Global study aims to uncover why accounting’s losing its shine

Her time is comfortably inside the world qualifying standard, and she has also set a world-qualifying time in the 200m butterfly event. With her impressive performances, Yu is considered a bright young star and could compete internationally in the world championships.

summary: US hostility towards energy-transition policies has sent a chill through European investing circles, where clean energy strategies are a major driver of flows. The House Republicans' bill to repeal the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act's incentives threatens to upend investment strategies, with analysts at Jefferies calling it "worse than feared" for investors committed to energy transition strategies. This uncertainty may force investors to turn to more stable jurisdictions like Canada or the EU, potentially leading to the US losing its status as a reliable investment destination.

site_title: US new-home sales jump to highest since 2022 as prices fall
summary: US new-home sales surged to a 11% increase in April, reaching the highest level since February 2022, driven by builder incentives and lower prices. The median sales price decreased 2% to $407,200, and the supply of new single-family homes for sale dipped slightly. However, sharp downward revisions to prior months tempered the optimism, and the inventory of homes remains high. Affordability challenges, including high mortgage rates near 7%, and consumer anxiety are expected to continue affecting the market.

summary: Malaysia is calling for the extension and expansion of a post-earthquake ceasefire in Myanmar, which is set to expire at the end of May. The ceasefire, declared by the ruling military junta after a devastating quake in March, has been extended before but fighting has continued, including airstrikes. Malaysian Foreign Minister Mohamad Hasan proposed the extension and expansion of ceasefires beyond the currently affected zones, urging stakeholders to cease hostilities and ease the suffering of the people of Myanmar.

site_title: Heir to US$27 billion Bharti fortune joins Britain’s wealth exodus
summary: Shravin Bharti Mittal, a 37-year-old heir to India's Bharti fortune, has relocated from Britain to the UAE amid the UK's tax reforms targeting non-domiciled residents. This move is part of a growing trend of wealthy individuals, including millennials, leaving the UK in response to the new tax regime. The UK's decision to scrap a preferential regime for non-doms and eliminate inheritance tax breaks on their overseas assets has led to an estimated quarter of its non-dom population considering or leaving the country, according to a think-tank study.

site_title: Advisory firm Glass Lewis backs Toyota chairman re-election
summary: Advisory firm Glass Lewis has recommended shareholders re-elect Toyota chairman Akio Toyoda at the automaker's annual general meeting in June. This marks a change from the past two years, where Glass Lewis had recommended a vote against him. Toyoda's position has come under scrutiny due to governance concerns, with his re-election support slipping to 72% in 2024 from 85% and 96% in the prior two years. Institutional Shareholder Services has also recommended re-electing Toyoda this year.

site_title: Spain considers new 21% VAT on short-tourism rentals, double the hotel rate
summary: The Spanish government is proposing a 21% value-added tax (VAT) on short-term tourism rentals, doubling the tax rate for hotel rooms, in an effort to address a housing crisis and balance maintaining tourism as its economic engine. The measure aims to apply to rentals under 30 days and affect around a third of annual visitors who opt for home rentals over hotels. The bill, which also includes a 100% tax on non-EU property purchases, faces opposition from landlords and associations, who argue it is discriminatory and could harm the tourism industry.

site_title: China’s GAC starts auto sales in Brazil, eyes local plant by late 2026
summary: Chinese automaker GAC has launched its product in Brazil, selling four imported electric cars and a hybrid model. The company plans to reach 100,000 sales in five years and expects to start building a factory in Brazil by late 2026. GAC's move comes as the Brazilian market sees growing competition and increasing demand for electrified vehicles, with sales jumping 37.4% year-on-year in the first four months of 2025. GAC's strategy is to tap into the country's large market and bilateral relationship with China.

summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong is attending the 46th Asean Summit in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, alongside regional counterparts and external partners China and the Gulf Cooperation Council. The summit, hosted by Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, aims to promote a free, open, and inclusive regional architecture amidst growing geopolitical and economic uncertainty. Discussions will focus on expanding Asean engagement with external partners and strengthening the bloc's resilience through intra-Asean trade and new growth areas.

China Investment Corporation and Danantara Indonesia entered an investment agreement, with no details provided. site_title: Indonesia to launch economic stimulus to boost consumption
summary: Indonesia plans to announce economic stimulus measures on June 5 to boost economic activity and consumer purchasing power. The measures include discounts on electricity bills, food handouts, and subsidies for electric motorcycle purchases. The country's central bank has trimmed its 2025 growth forecast to 4.6-5.4% from 4.7-5.5%. The stimulus packages aim to address the country's slow economic growth, with the first quarter showing a 4.87% growth rate, its weakest in over three years.

site_title: East Timor could join Asean bloc by October: minister
summary: East Timor is close to joining the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) by October, with Malaysia's foreign minister stating that the country has made progress in implementing a roadmap for membership. Despite challenges in infrastructure development and human resource capacity, Asean's foreign ministers have expressed strong support for Timor-Leste's full membership. The country's accession process is expected to be finalized by the 47th Asean Summit and Related Summits in October, with East Timor potentially becoming the bloc's 11th member state.

Trump recommended a 50% tariff on EU goods starting June 1 and threatened a 25% tariff on iPhones sold in the US. This sparked concerns of a global trade war, causing a sharp spike in the Euro Stoxx Volatility index and a 1.5% decline in euro zone stocks.

summary: The article argues that the claim that cheap solar and wind power is replacing fossil fuels is a misconception. Studies have shown that the real cost of solar power is often twice as high as coal, and solar and wind are many times more expensive than fossil fuels. Trump claimed the partnership will create at least 70,000 jobs and add $14 billion to the US economy. Governments in the region, such as China, India, Japan, Singapore, and South Korea, are enacting clear sustainability policies, giving brands a competitive edge. summary: The US dollar's decline since the start of 2025 has sparked speculation about its demise, with some suggesting it will be replaced. The Pentagon reviewed scripts for accuracy and depictions of the military, and the military also charged for equipment use, transportation, and lodging for personnel. The film's production team was able to take advantage of the carrier's scheduled training missions, logging most of the aircraft time as official training requirements, which were not reimbursable.

site_title: RBI’s record US$31.6 billion payout to bolster government finances
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has approved a record payout of $31.6 billion to the government, exceeding the budgeted estimate of $38.5 billion. This surplus will help meet India's 4.4% fiscal deficit target for the current financial year, bolstering growth in Asia's third-largest economy. The RBI's annual payout will also create a cushion for potential losses from import duty cuts and offset a shortfall in tax collections due to weak growth.

It will also steer the economy through challenges, reviewing and updating economic strategies, and working with tripartite partners to create good jobs. The government will continue efforts to refresh and strengthen Singapore's social compact, accelerating the transition to cleaner energy, and engaging Singaporeans in policy-making.

Welcome to the AI trough

A recent survey found 42% of companies abandoning AI pilot projects, with some, like Klarna, rehiring humans for roles previously automated. site_title: UBS to open Abu Dhabi office as more clients move to Mideast
summary: UBS is opening a new office in Abu Dhabi, capitalizing on the influx of wealthy individuals moving to the Middle East due to low-tax regimes. Abu Dhabi has emerged as a magnet for the world's wealthiest people, with 75 centi-millionaires already residing there, and is expected to see its population more than double in the next 10 years. The US Commerce Department has warned overseas companies against using Huawei's Ascend chips due to export controls, and the Trump administration is drafting new regulations to prevent the spread of Chinese AI technology. summary: Japan's exports rose 2% in April, matching a median forecast, but shipments to the US fell 1.8% due to the impact of US tariffs. The US has imposed 25% levies on cars, steel, and aluminum, significantly hurting Japan's economy, which relies heavily on US automobile exports. Japan's trade deficit widened to 115.8 billion yen in April, as imports fell 2.2% and automobile exports rose 11.8%. Japan's real GDP contracted an annualised 0.7 per cent in January-March, preliminary government data showed, much bigger than a median market forecast for a 0.2 per cent drop.

summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) adopted a landmark Pandemic Agreement on May 20, 2025, after three years of negotiations sparked by the Covid-19 crisis. The accord aims to improve global coordination and surveillance, and access to vaccines, in any future pandemics. The agreement was finalized by consensus, despite US withdrawal from the talks, and has been hailed as a victory for public health, science, and multilateral action. The Trump administration's tariffs campaign is disrupting global trade, with investors fearing a trade war that could erode US-China bilateral trade and decimate industries. Tensions remain high, with Beijing accusing the US of undermining recent trade talks.

site_title: Tariff mythbusters: Alternative perspectives on US tariffs
summary: US tariffs have sparked concerns about inflation and a potential recession, but alternative perspectives suggest that these outcomes are not inevitable. Tariffs can be inflationary, but they don't guarantee it, especially in cases where supply-demand imbalances and global competition mitigate inflationary effects. The example of medical gloves from Malaysia shows that tariffs don't always lead to price increases. In fact, tariffs can be seen as a consumption tax, similar to a value-added tax, and their impact is often temporary. Fiscal spending can also offset the economic drags caused by tariffs, and historical examples, such as the 1920s Roaring Twenties, show that tariffs alone do not dictate economic outcomes.

The proposals include streamlining prospectus disclosure requirements, easing listing criteria, and encouraging institutional investors to engage with companies and push for higher standards. The aim is to create a more conducive environment for promising new listings, with institutional investors playing a key stewardship role in the Singapore market.

summary: US-China tariffs are set to ease, potentially boosting tech stocks and the S&P500 index, according to Standard Chartered bank. The temporary tariff reversal is expected to alleviate concerns about a US growth slump and provide a tailwind to the ongoing equity rally. The bank also expects China's technology sector to benefit, with strong AI-driven earnings, government policy support, and attractive valuation. The financial sector is also expected to get a lift from a focus on easing regulations to boost lending.

InvoiceNow's technology integrates with the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) and the Media Development Authority (MDA) to streamline tax filing processes. This partnership is expected to reduce administrative burdens on businesses, making it easier for them to comply with tax regulations. The initiative is part of BT's efforts to support businesses in Singapore, particularly in terms of tax compliance and financial management.

summary: US President Donald Trump's sweeping tax-cut bill has won approval from a key congressional committee, advancing toward possible passage in the House of Representatives later this week. The bill, which would extend 2017 tax cuts, is expected to add $3 trillion to $5 trillion to the nation's debt over the next decade. The decision was made despite a downgrade by Moody's, citing rising debt that could reach 134% of GDP by 2035. The bill's passage is seen as a big win for Trump and House Speaker Mike Johnson, who aim to pass the bill before the Memorial Day holiday.

summary: Chinese billionaire Bian Ximing has built a nearly $1 billion bet on copper, making him the country's largest copper bull and Zhongcai Futures' largest net long position in copper contracts. Bian, who made $1.5 billion on gold trades, has been increasing his copper positions despite trade war uncertainties and some investors pulling out. His strategy focuses on long-term fundamentals, with the energy transition and limited mine supply driving copper prices. Bian's unassuming approach has garnered a loyal following in China for his Warren Buffett-like investment philosophy, with some rival traders describing his position as a bet on China's shift to a higher-tech economy.

site_title: Indonesia wages war on extortion that threatens to derail investor confidence
summary: Indonesian authorities have named suspects in a major extortion case targeting a multitrillion-rupiah chlor-alkali plant project in Cilegon, owned by Chandra Alkali, a subsidiary of Chandra Asri. The suspects include two prominent figures affiliated with the Indonesian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and one from a local fishermen's association. The extortion attempt involved demands for a project share worth five trillion rupiah outside the official tender process, highlighting persistent rent-seeking practices that undermine Indonesia's investment climate. The government has pledged to take firm action against extortion and illegal levies, with President Prabowo Subianto instructing law enforcement authorities to investigate and prosecute such cases thoroughly.

This move is part of Gulf's "normal investment" strategy, aiming to generate higher capital gains and dividends.

The investments aim to develop the zone's green economy, manufacturing, logistics, and healthcare sectors. Microsoft is also developing structured retrieval augmentation to help AI agents improve their memories, a key aspect of training a biological brain. The goal is to enable AI agents to work together and have better memories, leading to more effective and efficient collaboration.

summary: Thailand's economy grew 3.1% in Q1 2025, beating market expectations, but its full-year forecast was cut to 1.3-2.3% due to US tariffs threatening its export engine. A 36% tariff on shipments to the US, its largest export market, is set to expire in July unless a reduction is negotiated. The National Economic and Social Development Council (NESDC) also lowered its forecast for export growth to 1.8% and foreign tourist arrivals to 37 million this year.

The flats sold at HK$9,645 to HK$13,500 per square feet. A drop in interest rates, with the one-month Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate dipping below 1.3%, is helping the city's residential market. Analysts expect monthly new-home sales to jump 36% and home prices to rise, with some predicting the market may be at a "turning point".

site_title: China tells officials to rein in alcohol, cigarette spending
summary: China's government has reminded officials to cut wasteful spending on travel, food, and office space, as part of President Xi Jinping's campaign to reduce spending and address a huge debt burden. The notice, issued by the government and Communist Party, also targets outlays on receptions, alcohol, and cigarettes, urging officials to adopt "strict diligence and thrift" and avoid extravagance. This move is seen as part of Xi's efforts to rein in corruption and displays of wealth, amid a drop in revenue from land sales and local governments' huge debt burden.

summary: China's new home prices remained unchanged in April for a second month, extending a nearly two-year streak of no growth. Prices have declined 4% from a year earlier, a slight improvement from a 4.5% decline last month. Beijing has announced stimulus measures to bolster the economy, including trimming mortgage costs, but developers continue to struggle with repayments and confidence in the sector remains low. Separate data showed a 10.3% drop in property investment and a 2.8% decline in sales by floor area in January-April.

The firm is seeking an IPO for portfolio company Orion Breweries and is investing 100 billion yen in Japan for 2025. The duties are expected to affect various industries, including auto parts, electronics, and medical equipment.

The E33G visa, which permits multiple entries and allows holders to live and work in Indonesia for up to a year, has been approved for around 633 applicants, with 77% choosing Bali as their base. However, this influx of nomads has driven up housing costs, changed spending patterns, and raised concerns over affordability for locals. The shift from mass tourism to longer-staying digital guests has also contributed to traffic congestion, noise pollution, and safety issues.

site_title: Protecting capital in a market downturn
summary: Investors often fail to protect their capital in market downturns by holding on to stocks, thinking they will rebound. Trend following, as used by investors like Paul Tudor Jones and George Soros, can help mitigate this. By following the trend, investors can protect their capital in a falling market and profit from a rising one. The 200-day moving average is a key indicator for trend following, with historical evidence showing higher returns and lower volatility when the market is above this average. However, market timing can be challenging, and investors should be aware of false signals and whipsaws.

site_title: TikTok charged with breaching EU online content rules
summary: The European Commission has charged TikTok with breaching EU online content rules, specifically the Digital Services Act's obligation to publish an advertisement repository. The platform has failed to provide necessary information on advertisements, including who pays for them and how audiences are targeted. This breach could result in a fine of up to 6% of TikTok's global turnover. The EU executive is also investigating TikTok's management of risks related to elections.

images.alt_text: TikTok’s largest market by users is the US, but five of its 10 biggest globally are in South-east or South Asia, according to Kepios data.

site_title: FTX to distribute US$5 billion in next round of creditor payments
summary: FTX is set to distribute $5 billion to creditors in its second round of payments, with customers receiving between 54% and 120% of their owed amounts. The payments, starting on May 30, will be made through Bitgo or Kraken and are part of a court-approved Chapter 11 payment plan. FTX customers who held crypto on the platform will be repaid in cash, missing out on the rise in digital-asset values since its implosion. The company had approximately $12.6 billion in assets before filing for bankruptcy in November 2022.

site_title: Paramount’s ‘Mission: Impossible’ secures China release date
summary: Paramount's 'Mission: Impossible - The Final Reckoning' starring Tom Cruise has secured a release date in China, set for May 30. This marks the eighth film in the franchise, which has grossed over $4 billion worldwide, including $500 million from China. The decision comes after the Beijing government approved other Hollywood movies, such as Disney's 'Lilo & Stitch' and Universal's 'How to Train Your Dragon', following a statement in April that the US would face "moderate reduction" in allowed movies due to trade tensions.

site_title: As US, China reach a trade truce, these are the stocks to buy or avoid
summary: US and China have reached a trade truce, with the US cutting tariffs on Chinese goods to 30% from 145% and China lowering tariffs to 10% from 125%. This pause in tariffs has led to a rally in the S&P 500, with shares of Tesla and Nvidia jumping 5% and 5.6% respectively. Analysts remain cautious about tech stocks, citing concerns about the companies' economic moat. However, they see potential in China's communications and consumer sectors, including stocks like Baidu, Tencent, and Yum China. Meanwhile, Malaysian glove makers face uncertainty due to the reduced tariffs, which could lead to a less competitive rate for them in China.

site_title: ‘We are the ocean’
summary: The third United Nations Ocean Conference, hosted by France in Nice, aims to protect the oceans through tangible actions. The conference, attended by heads of state and government, researchers, and activists, focuses on high seas governance, financing a sustainable blue economy, and science and ocean literacy. The conference seeks to address pressing issues such as plastic pollution, overfishing, and ocean acidification, and to establish a global compact for the conservation and sustainable use of the oceans. A historic opportunity for multilateral action, the conference seeks to build on the Paris Agreement and previous UN conventions, with Singapore playing a crucial role in the negotiations.

site_title: China’s Pop Mart-loving Gen Z fuels big gains for investors
summary: China's Gen Z consumers are driving economic growth by boosting consumption and stimulating domestic demand, helping offset the damage from tariffs. The younger generation is spending big on hobbies, such as toys, celebrity merchandise, and trendy jewelry, defying a wider malaise in the economy. Stocks of companies catering to Gen Z, including Pop Mart International Group, have soared, with some doubling in value this year. The spending boom offers a glimmer of hope for China's economy, which is still recovering from a years-long property slump and dealing with deflation and US tariffs.

images.alt_text: The fervour for Pop Mart’s toys has turned it into a global phenomenon, with fans sometimes queueing for hours outside stores for new releases.

site_title: Ex-Goldman banker leads China’s push to revive Hong Kong finance
summary: China's former Goldman Sachs banker Qi Bin has been appointed to lead the country's push to revive Hong Kong's finance sector. Qi, who is fluent in English, has met with major banks, regulators, and investors, proposing a White Paper and timetable for market improvements to meet global standards. His proposals include reforms on corporate governance, trading costs, and initial public offerings. Qi's assertive approach has raised concerns among local officials, but his Western education and Wall Street background are seen as a welcome departure from typical mainland Chinese officials.

site_title: Singapore biotech firm Mirxes launches IPO in Hong Kong to raise HK$1 billion
summary: Singapore biotech firm Mirxes launched its IPO in Hong Kong, raising HK$1.09 billion (S$181 million) to further grow its business. The company, which offers a cancer diagnostics product, plans to use half of the funds for research and development, and the remaining for manufacturing and commercialization. The shares are expected to start trading on May 23, with 90% of the offer going to international investors and 10% to public subscription in Hong Kong. Beijing Xunrui Enterprise Management Partnership and Evergreen Gate have subscribed to shares worth US$57.92 million.

site_title: Chinese disinflation wave is set to boost emerging-market bonds
summary: A Chinese disinflation wave, driven by redirected exports away from the US due to higher tariffs, is expected to boost emerging-market bonds. As US interest rates remain high, central banks in countries with high Chinese import ratios, such as Malaysia, Brazil, and South Africa, are likely to cut interest rates, making longer-maturity debt more attractive. This trend is expected to continue despite some concerns about the impact of cheap Chinese imports on local markets.

site_title: DPM Heng hopes to spend time with family, travel, ‘not do any work’ in first year of retirement
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat is retiring from politics after 14 years in the Government, citing his desire to spend time with family, travel, and pursue hobbies without work. He plans to spend 6-12 months not working before deciding on his next steps, with a focus on health and personal interests. Heng, 64, has no intention of returning to public life, but may return to areas like science, technology, and innovation, which he has previously covered.

site_title: Japfa expected to delist on Jun 10 as court sanctions scheme of arrangement
summary: Japfa, a Singaporean agri-food company, is expected to delist from the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange on June 10 after the court sanctioned its scheme of arrangement to take the business private. The last day of trading will be May 16, and trading will be suspended from May 19. Shareholders will receive S$0.62 per share in cash on or around June 6. The company's shareholders, led by the Santosa siblings and their cousin, will acquire the business for a 34.8% premium to the counter's last traded price.

site_title: Mortgage rates in the US rise, sending 30-year average to 6.81%
summary: US mortgage rates have risen for the first time in four weeks, reaching 6.81% for 30-year, fixed loans, according to Freddie Mac. This increase is linked to traders' response to US President Donald Trump's trade wars and tariffs. Despite this, a key consumer price measure rose less than expected in April, and homebuyers are waiting out the turmoil, with signed contracts down 3% from last year. The US Federal Reserve is expected to hold interest rates steady, and inventory levels have reached their highest in over five years, offering more choices for buyers.

site_title: Putin ‘must pay the price for avoiding peace’ in Ukraine: Britain’s Starmer
summary: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer has stated that Russian President Vladimir Putin "must pay the price for avoiding peace" in Ukraine, calling his tactics "intolerable." Ahead of a European Political Community meeting in Albania, Starmer said Putin's refusal to negotiate a ceasefire will lead to widespread sanctions. The meeting comes as talks between Ukraine and Russia in Turkey are expected to take place, but neither Putin nor Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky are expected to attend.

The offeror, DRC Investments, has acquired 522.5 million shares, representing 90.88% of Amara's total shares. summary: Geely appoints Andy An, CEO of its electric car brand Zeekr, as the new head of the company after its US-listed premium electric car brand was taken private at a valuation of $6.4 billion. The move is seen as a response to intense competition in China's car market. Current CEO Daniel Li will become executive vice chairman of Geely Holding Group after the merger. The leadership shakeup comes as Geely continues to enjoy strong growth in China, with deliveries rising 48% in the first three months of the year.

Container carriers, including Hapag-Lloyd, are seeing stronger demand, but the current 30% US tariff rate is expected to still hurt demand. summary: LHN's net profit for the first half of 2025 rose 8.8% to S$14.1 million, driven primarily by revenue contributions from its property development business and co-living segment. The group's revenue increased 29.4% to S$70.6 million, with earnings per share rising 6.6%. LHN attributed the growth to new integrated facilities management contracts and car park management projects, as well as the cessation of less efficient projects. The company remains cautiously optimistic on demand for short-term and long-term rentals in 2025.

summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat has announced his retirement after serving in various key roles, including Education and Finance ministries. Heng's time as finance minister was marked by presenting five budgets during the Covid-19 pandemic and raising the goods and services tax to fund healthcare expenditure. He emphasized the need for long-term planning, embracing technological changes, and addressing climate change and a rapidly ageing population.

summary: Ant Group, backed by Jack Ma, reported a 31% decline in profit to 1.76 billion yuan (S$317.5 million) in the three months ended Dec 31, driven by investments in AI and new business costs. Despite a surge in the previous quarter, Ant's earnings lag behind Alibaba's. The company is seeking a turnaround by expanding its AI capabilities, including developing techniques for training AI models using Chinese-made semiconductors.

US President Donald Trump stated that the US is close to securing a nuclear deal with Iran, while an Iranian official expressed willingness to agree to a deal in exchange for lifting economic sanctions. This could unlock an additional 0.8 million barrels per day of Iranian crude, bearish for prices.
